metadata.titleEn: Hourly soil moisture dataset observed by eco-hydrological sensor network in the upper reaches of Heihe River (2013-2017)
metadata.description: Soil moisture is one of the core variables in the water cycle. Although its variation is very small, for a precipitation process, soil moisture directly determines the transformation of precipitation into evaporation, runoff and groundwater, which is very important to finely simulate spatial-temporal dynamics of various variables in hydrological process and to accurately estimate water inflow in the upper reaches of Heihe River. This dataset includes soil moisture and temperature data observed by 40 nodes from July 2013 to December 2017. Each node in Babao River Basin has soil moisture observation at depth of 4cm and 20cm; some nodes also include observations at depth of 10 cm. The data observation frequency is 1 hour. The dataset can provide ground -based observations for hydrological simulation, data assimilation and remote sensing verification.

background: Ecological and hydrological monitoring are essential for understanding basin-scale ecohydrological processes, obtaining baseline data for assessment of impacts and conservation of regional ecosystems, and for the development and validation of ecohydrological models (Brierley et al. 2010). Remote sensing data have advantages in that they facilitate a relatively cheap and rapid means of acquiring up-to-date information over a large geographic area. However, validation studies have shown that these products may be biased (Turneret al. 2006). Traditional fixed-point observation stations such as hydrological and meteorological stations and flux towers yield more accurate observations. However, their high cost, high risk and intensive labour needs limit high-density deployment in a large river basin (Zhanget al.2012). The emergence of wireless sensor network (WSN) technology has brought new opportunities for data-intensive observation in ecohydrological research and environmental monitoring (Hart and Martinez2006). For watershed monitoring, an ecohydrological WSN integrates a variety of environmental observations, data processing, wireless communication and energy supply into a sensor node. This forms the WSN with a self-organizing approach, to achieve real-time sensing, monitoring, collecting and processing of information on various hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables (Zhang et al. 2012). It represents an intensive low-cost observation technique, which enhances basin ecohydrological monitoring capabilities.
research objective: This article presents a geostatistical method for multivariate sampling design optimization, using a universal cokriging (UCK) model. The optimized WSN design is efficient in capturing spatial variation of the target variables and for monitoring ecohydrological processes in the Babao River basin.
challenges: Since there was no sampling in the study area prior to designing the sampling scheme, remote sensing products and model data were used to provide primary information on the targets such as variograms for LMC. Since the auxiliary maps (Figure 3) show averages for a given time, whereas the three target variables vary in space and time, those maps cannot be used to depict the target variables and were only used to calibrate the UCK model. We assumed that these auxiliary maps could represent the spatial correlation structure and relationships with the covariates. However, two issues need to be addressed, as follows. (a) Scale issue: spatial resolutions of auxiliary maps of LST, precipitation and soil moisture are 1 km; therefore, the maps represent spatial patterns of target variables at 1-km scale. This scale may not be the same as that of spatial patterns characterized by WSN samples on target variables. (b) Uncertainty issue: the data may have uncertainties stemming from remote sensing data and the model. For example, TWI, which was used to represent soil moisture, is affected not only by terrain but also by other factors such as meteorological conditions and land cover. Therefore, TWI will directly affect LMC fitting and sampling optimization results. The trend elimination process and residual error of LMC fitting also introduce uncertainties in the optimization process, which affects the accuracy and reliability of WSN sampling design.
methods: After removal of spatial trends in the target variables by multiple linear regression, variograms and cross-variograms of regression residuals are fit with the linear model of coregionalization. Using weighted mean UCK variance as the objective function, the optimal sampling design is obtained using a spatially simulated annealing algorithm.
findings: The results demonstrate that the UCK model-based sampling method can consider the relationship of target variables and environmental covariates, and spatial auto- and cross-correlation of regression residuals, to obtain the optimal design in geographic space and attribute space simultaneously. Compared with a sampling design without consideration of the multivariate (cross-)correlation and spatial trend, the proposed sampling method reduces prediction error variance.

background: The high spatio-temporal resolution of soil moisture distributions plays an important role in ecological and hydrological processes at the basin scale. From the perspective of ecology, soil moisture is related to plant growth and influences the structure, function and diversity of vegetation, especially in arid and semiarid regions. From a hydrologic perspective, soil moisture controls the rainfall-runoff response, particularly when the soil is already saturated. The lack of soil moisture data with high spatio-temporal resolutions is one of the largest sources of uncertainty in such models. Therefore, at the basin scale, high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture products can be used to understand eco-hydrological processes, calibrate parameters in hydrological models, and improve the prediction ability of hydrological data assimilation systems. However, the soil moisture remote sensing products currently available and operable have resolutions of 25-40 km, which cannot meet the requirements of water cycle research and water resource management at the basin scale. These simulated or assimilated soil moisture products are highly dependent on atmospheric forcing. However, observations of key forcing parameters, such as air temperature, precipitation, wind speed and humidity, are sparse. Therefore, it is difficult to accurately simulate soil moisture dynamics at the basin scale. Thus, the aforementioned methods may not be optimal for providing the spatio-temporal characteristics of soil moisture at the basin scale.
research objective: In this study, we analyze the spatio-temporal distribution and dynamic characteristics of soil moisture at the basin scale, especially under complex topography conditions, and attempt to derive high spatio-temporal resolution maps of soil moisture by integrating WSN multi-point observations and auxiliary remote sensing information. A Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm and MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia are used to estimate daily soil moisture at a resolution of 1 km. The estimation accuracy is evaluated based on automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and the SMOS soil moisture product. Finally, the mapping results are analyzed to understand the spatio-temporal characteristics of soil moisture.
challenges: However, RK is unable to handle the nonlinear relationship between soil moisture and the auxiliary data. All the above methods require numerous observation sites to capture the spatial characteristics of soil moisture, and determining the spatial autocorrelation is challenging using only a few observation sites. However, in a basin with complex topography, the WSN distribution would appear sparse, regardless of its spatial coverage and density. Therefore, it is infeasible to map soil moisture based on the above methods in a mountainous area with drastic terrain relief.
methods: A Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm that utilizes MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia is used to map daily soil moisture spatial patterns with a resolution of 1 km in the Babao River Basin, China. The 2-4 cm soil moisture observations from seven automatic meteorological stations located in different elevation zones from 3000 m to 3500 m are employed to validate the mapping algorithm. Semivariograms and an empirical orthogonal function (EOF) analysis are used to analyze the space-time heterogeneities of soil moisture at the 1 km scale.
dataset: The 2-4 cm soil moisture observations from seven automatic meteorological stations located in different elevation zones from 3000 m to 3500 m are employed to validate the mapping algorithm.
findings: The correlation coefficient and unbiased root-mean-square error (RMSE) averaged 0.880 and 0.031 cm3/cm3, respectively, which indicate satisfactory estimation accuracy. The results show that both products exhibit strong temporal consistency; however, due to complex topography, the SMOS soil moisture is generally lower than that of the upscaling results. From the perspective of temporal variation, the upscaled soil moisture shows a well-defined seasonal cycle, which represents the effects of decreased rainfall from August to October. Based on a validation analysis of the mapping results, the upscaling method is proven feasible, and the upscaled soil moisture can be used to analyze eco-hydrological processes and validate remote sensing products.

Definition.Question: What is the role of a wireless sensor network (WSN) in ecohydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: A wireless sensor network (WSN) in ecohydrological data collection integrates a variety of environmental observations, data processing, wireless communication, and energy supply into a sensor node. This forms the WSN with a self-organizing approach to achieve real-time sensing, monitoring, collecting, and processing of information on various hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables, enhancing basin ecohydrological monitoring capabilities.

Definition.Question: How does a Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm contribute to soil moisture mapping in complex topography?
Definition.Answer: A Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm contributes to soil moisture mapping in complex topography by integrating WSN multi-point observations and auxiliary remote sensing information, using MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia to estimate daily soil moisture at a resolution of 1 km. This approach helps in capturing the spatio-temporal distribution and dynamic characteristics of soil moisture at the basin scale.

Comparison.Question: How do wireless sensor networks (WSNs) compare to traditional fixed-point observation stations in terms of data collection efficiency and spatial coverage for ecohydrological monitoring?
Comparison.Answer: Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) offer a low-cost, intensive observation technique that enhances basin ecohydrological monitoring capabilities by integrating various environmental observations, data processing, wireless communication, and energy supply into a sensor node. Unlike traditional fixed-point observation stations, which provide more accurate observations but are limited by high costs and labor needs, WSNs enable high-density deployment and real-time sensing over large areas.

Comparison.Question: How does the application of a Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm using MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia compare to regression kriging (RK) in addressing spatial and temporal heterogeneity in soil moisture mapping?
Comparison.Answer: The Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm using MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia effectively handles nonlinear relationships and provides high-resolution soil moisture maps (1 km resolution) under complex topography conditions, showing strong temporal consistency and accurate seasonal cycle representation. Regression kriging (RK), however, struggles with nonlinear relationships and requires numerous observation sites to capture spatial characteristics, making it less feasible in areas with drastic terrain relief.

Interpretation.Question: How can wireless sensor network technology improve data collection accuracy and efficiency in ecohydrological research despite challenges associated with high-density deployment?
Interpretation.Answer: Wireless sensor network technology offers a low-cost, intensive observation technique that integrates various environmental observations, data processing, wireless communication, and energy supply into a sensor node. This self-organizing approach allows for real-time sensing and monitoring of hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables, thereby enhancing ecohydrological monitoring capabilities at the basin level.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential implications of high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture data on ecological and hydrological modeling at the basin scale?
Interpretation.Answer: High spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture data are crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes, calibrating parameters in hydrological models, and improving the prediction ability of hydrological data assimilation systems. Such data help address uncertainties in models and can significantly influence ecological studies related to plant growth and hydrological studies on rainfall-runoff responses, especially in arid and semiarid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited deployment of high-density observation stations in large river basins for ecohydrological monitoring?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high cost, high risk, and intensive labor needs associated with traditional fixed-point observation stations, such as hydrological and meteorological stations and flux towers, limit their high-density deployment in large river basins.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately simulate soil moisture dynamics at the basin scale using current remote sensing products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Current remote sensing products for soil moisture have resolutions of 25-40 km, which cannot meet the requirements for water cycle research and water resource management at the basin scale. Additionally, these products are highly dependent on atmospheric forcing, and observations of key forcing parameters are sparse, making it difficult to accurately simulate soil moisture dynamics at the basin scale.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes uncertainties in the sampling design optimization process for ecohydrological monitoring using wireless sensor networks?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in the sampling design optimization process may stem from the spatial resolutions of auxiliary maps, which may not match the spatial patterns characterized by wireless sensor network samples. Additionally, uncertainties arise from the trend elimination process and residual errors of linear model of coregionalization fitting, as well as from remote sensing data and model uncertainties affecting the auxiliary data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a wireless sensor network (WSN) for ecohydrological monitoring in a river basin?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a WSN for ecohydrological monitoring in a river basin offers intensive, low-cost observation capabilities that enhance monitoring by integrating various environmental observations. This approach allows for real-time sensing, monitoring, collecting, and processing of information related to hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables, thus improving the ability to capture spatial variations and monitor ecohydrological processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating WSN multi-point observations with remote sensing data for soil moisture estimation under complex topography conditions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating WSN multi-point observations with remote sensing data allows for the derivation of high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture maps, which are crucial for analyzing soil moisture dynamics in regions with complex topography. This integration helps overcome limitations of remote sensing products with lower resolutions and sparse observation sites, thus improving the ability to capture spatial and temporal variations in soil moisture for eco-hydrological studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective behind integrating wireless sensor network (WSN) technology for soil moisture data collection in ecohydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of integrating wireless sensor network (WSN) technology in ecohydrological research is to enhance basin ecohydrological monitoring capabilities through intensive low-cost observation, enabling real-time sensing, monitoring, collecting, and processing of information on various hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be employed to optimize multivariate sampling design for observing soil moisture variations in a river basin using wireless sensor networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A geostatistical method using a universal cokriging (UCK) model can be employed to optimize multivariate sampling design. This involves removing spatial trends in the target variables through multiple linear regression, fitting variograms and cross-variograms of regression residuals with a linear model of coregionalization, and using a spatially simulated annealing algorithm to obtain an optimal sampling design.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data be integrated with wireless sensor network observations to enhance the mapping of soil moisture spatial patterns in regions with complex topography?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm utilizing MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia can be used to map daily soil moisture spatial patterns. This method involves validating the mapping algorithm with soil moisture observations from automatic meteorological stations at various elevations and analyzing space-time heterogeneities through semivariograms and empirical orthogonal function (EOF) analysis.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the deployment of wireless sensor networks (WSN) for intensive ecohydrological monitoring in river basins?
Enablement.Answer: The emergence of wireless sensor network (WSN) technology has brought new opportunities for data-intensive observation in ecohydrological research and environmental monitoring. A WSN integrates various environmental observations, data processing, wireless communication, and energy supply into a sensor node, forming a self-organizing network that can achieve real-time sensing, monitoring, collecting, and processing of information on hydrological, ecological, and meteorological variables.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing data and wireless sensor networks (WSN) facilitate the optimization of sampling designs for ecohydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data with WSN technology allows for the optimization of sampling designs by providing primary information on target variables. This includes the use of variograms for linear models of coregionalization (LMC) and universal cokriging (UCK) models, which help capture spatial variation of the target variables and monitor ecohydrological processes efficiently. This approach also considers the spatial auto- and cross-correlation of regression residuals.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the estimation of high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture maps in complex topography areas?
Enablement.Answer: A Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm utilizing MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia enables the estimation of high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture maps in complex topography areas. This method employs observations from automatic meteorological stations for validation and uses semivariograms and empirical orthogonal function (EOF) analysis to analyze the space-time heterogeneities of soil moisture at a 1 km scale.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected outcomes of soil moisture mapping at a basin scale be challenging to achieve using available remote sensing products?
Expectation.Answer: The expected outcomes may be challenging due to the limited spatial resolution of remote sensing products, which typically have resolutions of 25-40 km, insufficient for capturing detailed soil moisture variability at the basin scale. Additionally, the dependency on sparse atmospheric forcing data, such as air temperature and precipitation, makes it difficult to accurately simulate soil moisture dynamics in complex topography areas.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional fixed-point observation stations not meet the expected needs for high-density deployment in large river basins?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional fixed-point observation stations may not meet expected needs due to their high cost, high risk, and intensive labor requirements, which limit their deployment density across large river basins. These constraints hinder their ability to provide comprehensive spatial coverage and real-time data required for detailed ecohydrological monitoring.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be uncertainty in expected results when using auxiliary maps for sampling design optimization in ecohydrological studies?
Expectation.Answer: There could be uncertainty because auxiliary maps, which have a spatial resolution of 1 km, may not accurately represent the spatial patterns of target variables at different scales. Additionally, uncertainties may arise from remote sensing data and model-derived variables affecting the optimization process, such as terrain-based TWI, which is influenced by factors like meteorological conditions and land cover, leading to potential inaccuracies in sampling design.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and limitations one might face when integrating remote sensing data and WSN observations to derive high spatio-temporal resolution maps of soil moisture?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data and WSN observations faces challenges including the scale issue, where auxiliary maps may not reflect the spatial patterns characterized by WSN samples, and uncertainty stemming from remote sensing data and model dependencies. The complex topography and sparse distribution of WSN in such areas also pose challenges in accurately mapping soil moisture.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the limitations of using simulated or assimilated soil moisture products for understanding eco-hydrological processes at the basin scale?
Judgmental.Answer: Simulated or assimilated soil moisture products often have resolutions of 25-40 km, which are insufficient for basin-scale water cycle research and water resource management. They are highly dependent on atmospheric forcing, and the sparse observations of key parameters make it difficult to accurately simulate soil moisture dynamics at the basin scale, thereby limiting their effectiveness in understanding eco-hydrological processes.

Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the inability of certain methods like RK to handle nonlinear relationships between soil moisture and auxiliary data, and the sparse distribution of WSN due to complex topography, which makes it difficult to determine spatial autocorrelation and map soil moisture in regions with drastic terrain relief.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with the use of wireless sensor networks for soil moisture data collection in regions with complex topography, and suggest potential solutions to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include handling the nonlinear relationship between soil moisture and auxiliary data, and determining spatial autocorrelation with limited observation sites. In regions with complex topography, the wireless sensor network (WSN) distribution may appear sparse despite its coverage and density. Potential solutions involve integrating remote sensing information and using advanced algorithms like a Bayesian-based upscaling algorithm that utilizes MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia to improve mapping accuracy at a finer spatial resolution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used to optimize wireless sensor network sampling designs for monitoring ecohydrological processes, and evaluate their effectiveness in capturing spatial variations of target variables.
Request/Directive.Answer: Optimizing wireless sensor network sampling designs involves geostatistical methods like universal cokriging (UCK) to efficiently capture spatial variations. The optimized design considers relationships between target variables and environmental covariates, and spatial auto- and cross-correlation of regression residuals. The effectiveness is demonstrated by reducing prediction error variance compared to designs without consideration of multivariate correlations and spatial trends, thereby improving monitoring of ecohydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss data collection methods for achieving high spatio-temporal resolution soil moisture observations in large river basins, and propose improvements to enhance their accuracy and reliability.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods include combining wireless sensor networks with remote sensing products to map soil moisture distributions. High spatio-temporal resolution is achieved using upscaling algorithms like Bayesian-based techniques that incorporate MODIS-derived apparent thermal inertia. Improvements can focus on addressing uncertainties from remote sensing data and model dependencies by calibrating with ground-based observations and enhancing auxiliary data resolution, thus increasing accuracy and reliability in capturing soil moisture dynamics.
